name: Mercury
shortDescription: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and the closest to the Sun.
detailedDescription: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and the closest to the Sun. It is only slightly larger than Earth's Moon. Despite being closest to the Sun, it's not the hottest planet - that title goes to Venus. Mercury has no atmosphere to retain heat, so temperatures swing wildly from 430°C during the day to -180°C at night. Its surface is heavily cratered, much like our Moon, showing billions of years of impacts. Mercury orbits the Sun faster than any other planet, completing a year in just 88 Earth days.
funFacts: Mercury has wrinkles called lobate scarps, caused by the planet shrinking as it cooled.
A year on Mercury is just 88 Earth days, but a day is 59 Earth days.
It is the second densest planet after Earth.
Mercury has ice at its poles in permanently shadowed craters.

name: Venus
shortDescription: Venus is Earth's toxic twin, with crushing pressure and acid rain.
detailedDescription: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and is often called Earth's twin due to its similar size. However, it's a hellish world with a thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide that traps heat, making it the hottest planet in our solar system at 464°C - hot enough to melt lead. The atmospheric pressure on Venus is 92 times that of Earth, equivalent to being 900 meters underwater. Clouds of sulfuric acid rain down but evaporate before reaching the scorching surface. Venus rotates backwards compared to other planets, so the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east.
funFacts: Venus spins backwards - the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east.
It is the hottest planet in our solar system due to runaway greenhouse effect.
A day on Venus is longer than a Venus year.
Venus is the brightest planet in Earth's night sky.

name: Earth
shortDescription: Earth is our home - the only known planet with life and liquid water.
detailedDescription: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life. Our planet is a water world, with about 71% of its surface covered by oceans. Earth is the densest planet in our solar system and the largest of the terrestrial planets. Its atmosphere, primarily nitrogen and oxygen, protects us from harmful solar radiation and keeps temperatures suitable for life. Earth's Moon stabilizes our planet's axial tilt, giving us predictable seasons.
funFacts: Earth is the only planet not named after a Greek or Roman god.
The Earth is the densest planet in the Solar System.
70% of Earth's surface is covered in water.
Earth's magnetic field protects us from solar wind.

name: Mars
shortDescription: Mars is the Red Planet, featuring the largest volcano and canyon in the solar system.
detailedDescription: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface. Mars hosts Olympus Mons, the largest volcano in the solar system - three times the height of Mount Everest - and Valles Marineris, a canyon system that would stretch across the entire United States. Evidence suggests Mars once had liquid water flowing on its surface, and NASA's rovers continue to search for signs of ancient microbial life.
funFacts: Mars is home to the largest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons.
Mars has the largest dust storms in the solar system, lasting for months.
Sunsets on Mars are blue due to fine dust in the atmosphere.
A Mars day (sol) is only 40 minutes longer than an Earth day.

name: Jupiter
shortDescription: Jupiter is the king of planets - a gas giant with 95 known moons.
detailedDescription: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System. This gas giant is so massive that it could fit all other planets inside it and still have room to spare. It is made mostly of hydrogen and helium, similar to the Sun. Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a storm that has been raging for at least 400 years and is larger than Earth. Jupiter has at least 95 known moons, including the four large Galilean moons.
funFacts: Jupiter has the shortest day of all the planets - just 10 hours.
The Great Red Spot is a storm that has raged for at least 400 years.
Jupiter has a faint ring system discovered in 1979.
Jupiter acts as a 'cosmic vacuum cleaner', protecting inner planets.

name: Saturn
shortDescription: Saturn is the ringed wonder, with spectacular rings made of ice and rock.
detailedDescription: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest in the Solar System. It is famous for its stunning ring system, made up of billions of particles of ice and rock. Saturn is a gas giant composed mainly of hydrogen and helium. Despite its enormous size, Saturn is the least dense planet - it could float in water! Saturn has at least 146 known moons, including Titan with its thick atmosphere and Enceladus with its water geysers.
funFacts: Saturn is the flattest planet due to its fast rotation.
Saturn could theoretically float in water.
Its rings are made of ice and rock, some pieces as large as houses.
Saturn has hexagonal-shaped storms at its poles.

name: Uranus
shortDescription: Uranus is the sideways planet, spinning on its side with a unique axial tilt.
detailedDescription: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and is often called an 'ice giant' due to its composition of water, methane, and ammonia ices. What makes Uranus truly unique is its extreme axial tilt of 98 degrees - it essentially rotates on its side, possibly due to a collision with an Earth-sized object long ago. Uranus appears blue-green due to methane in its atmosphere. It has 27 known moons, all named after characters from Shakespeare and Alexander Pope.
funFacts: Uranus rotates on its side with an axial tilt of 98 degrees.
It was the first planet discovered using a telescope (1781).
Uranus is the coldest planetary atmosphere in the solar system.
All of Uranus's moons are named after Shakespearean characters.

name: Neptune
shortDescription: Neptune is the windiest planet, with storms reaching supersonic speeds.
detailedDescription: Neptune is the eighth and farthest known planet from the Sun. It is an ice giant like Uranus, with a vivid blue color caused by methane in its atmosphere. Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system, reaching speeds up to 2,100 km/hour. It was the first planet located through mathematical predictions rather than observation. Neptune has 14 known moons, with Triton being the largest - an unusual moon that orbits backwards.
funFacts: Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system at 2,100 km/h.
It was discovered through mathematics before being observed.
Neptune completed its first orbit since discovery in 2011.
Triton is one of the few moons with its own atmosphere.

name: Pluto
shortDescription: Pluto is the beloved dwarf planet at the edge of our solar system.
detailedDescription: Pluto is a dwarf planet in the Kuiper Belt, a region of icy bodies beyond Neptune's orbit. Once considered the ninth planet, Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006. Despite its small size (smaller than Earth's Moon), Pluto has a complex geology with mountains of water ice as tall as the Rockies, glaciers of frozen nitrogen, and a thin atmosphere. NASA's New Horizons spacecraft flew by Pluto in 2015, revealing a heart-shaped nitrogen plain called Tombaugh Regio.
funFacts: Pluto is smaller than Russia.
Pluto has a heart-shaped glacier called Tombaugh Regio.
It was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.
Pluto and its moon Charon orbit each other like a double planet.
